String thing: I posted a comment on a physics blog regarding my understanding and debunking of dark energy" http://blog.physicsworld.com/2015/06/08/is-dark-energy-becoming-marginal...

Then this blog post disappeared for a while but now it is back without posting my comment.

Why did I post it other places originally? Because each field is guarded, apprehensive, and there are plusses and minuses to this.

I think that physics students are not encouraged to think abstractly like Einstein did, and neither are any other scientists. Often the answers lie in abstract thinking, and this is my greatest strength.

The WSJ didn't understand closed economies. They believed in totally open, infinite markets and economies. It probably served many well to be that myopic.

It should be obvious what is happening now.

No doubt, the money the Fed creates bleaches into various areas of the economy: for starters, one would think the value of a bank share would go up - but it appears that is has helped the value of all stocks. Cheap money helps real estate to go up as well. But the real point is we need demand side bias policy to escape our supply side disfunction.

Demand side bias policy has to come, mostly, from the political branches of our system. Bernie's trillion dollar infrastructure program would be just a start. A higher minimum wage would probably help. Enhanced bargaining power for workers of all stripes would help to, because, ultimately demand comes from wages.

Congress refused to do anything. So, we are hosed.

Lee Harrison, 14 June post

Dear Dr. Harrison,

It is a curious shift from solar-powered aircraft to the racing of riding lawn-mowers, but whatinell, I'm with you.

Who cares if gentlemen of whatever age, with whatever headgear they choose, amuse themselves by racing riding lawn-mowers?

Live and let live, say I.

I don't seek their approval for my amusements and I certainly feel no urge to censure theirs.

As long as they buy their own gasoline, they have my blessing and best wishes.

I am well assured that their riding lawn-mowers are gasoline-powered since no riding electric lawn-mowers presently exist. And if they did, racing them would be like racing snails, or measuring continental drift.

Forgive me if I return to the presenting topic of the Solar Impulse.

I see that it took the Solar Impulse 150 million euros expenditure to reach Hawaii, at which point they paused to raise another 20 million euros to finish their circumnavigation.

Piccard admits that the flight will not transform aviation but rather is to "raise awareness", "educate the common man about clean energy" and other such vague pseudo-goals.

"Awareness" must have been in a truly dismal state, buried somewhere down below the Marianas Trench, if it requires 170 million euros to raise it!

I note however that the Solar Impulse is funded by private money, except for a $6.5 million grant from the Swiss government.

If I were Swiss, I'd be cross.

Since I'm not, I can be philosophical about it.

Deductibles and coinsurance have gone through the roof. The average person either never gets to the point where they are actually being reimbursed, or their healthcare providers engage in over-charging simply to get their patients past their deductible and coinsurance hurdles.

Thus it seems healthcare costs are rising, when really it is rational decision-making by patients and providers to get a fair level of coverage.

Folks often forego non-critical checkups and treatments now to save money since they pay 100% of the costs, which they cannot afford. Putting off healthcare raises the risk of serious illnesses down the road, which not only lowers the quality of life, but also increases future healthcare costs. These poor decisions are being encouraged by the insurance companies.

The system is SOOO broken. But do not blame Obama. This legislation was the only solution with any chance of passing, to address the worst inequities of the old system (pre-existing illness exclusion and the many uninsured).

One day, single provider will be the only option left to try. "You can always count on Americans to do the right thing - after they've tried everything else." (Winston Churchill)

I have been in one city in which water transit worked brilliantly:  Brisbane, Australia.  It works because of the distinctive topography.  Brisbane is built on a series of hills among which the Brisbane River meanders in a shape not unlike the human intestinal tract.  The City Cat zigzags from one side of the river to the other as it winds among the hills and their various neighborhoods.  It is an efficient way to get from the central business district to the arts and performance spaces on South Bank, or to the University of Queensland and a number of inner-city neighborhoods lining the various bends and turns of the river.  Trains and busses are also provided but for moving around the main parts of the older core of the city nothing can beat the City Cat.  The water ways around the NYC boroughs are not as contorted as the Brisbane River but if the routes were to zigzag from one bank to the other they might serve a lot more people than at first seems possible.

NYC is going down the drain because it appears that unfettered (and city-supported) development of luxury housing for the wealthy is now considered more important than anything else, including the unsexy stuff like being able to GET somewhere by subway or bus, having enough schools, hospitals, etc.

NYC is becoming enormously over-built with no corresponding increase in support services. I guess the silicon-valley-east types will just Uber to their destinations; only the poor and "ordinary" will take the nearly-dysfunctional subways & buses.

Maybe de Blasio can give each of us a personal transportation drone - get picked up at your home, get dropped off right in front of your office building.

The ferry idea will turn out to be an over-budget, behind-schedule boondoggle - and it really seems like just one more re-election ploy by de Blasio.
